comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content:
Interesting to see the man walking down the train, if I'm not mistaken he may be setting the brakes on the wagons as, judging from the variety of wagons, this is a stopping goods.

Incidentally trains carrying cars were unusual, the habit of many dealers at this time was to drive them straight from the docks. These were possibly from limerick, bound for Castlebar or thereabouts

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: The engine on the left appears to be a J19 class and seems to be shunting at least one wagon filled with turf briquettes

comment._content: Thanks for putting up a picture of my home town!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I wonder does it say Falstaff? That could be either beer or cigars.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: A very nice view of Claremorris before it was rebuilt in early 50s (1951/52). The building on the left isn't the waiting shelter, but the old locomotive shed for the Ballinrobe branch engines, you can see the ventilation in the roof section. The shed was demolished to allow an additional platform and track to built on that side of the station.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: I am going to make a Cork link and make a (fairly reasonable IMO) suggestion that these Fords are on their way up from the Cork factory. In July 1950, the 75,000th vehicle rolled off the line at Cork - it was a Prefect ("Ireland's most popular car"). The van at the front could be a specifically built Ford commercial (like the E83W) or a "van version" of either the Prefect or Anglia. As we often find with these 1950s/60s photos it's almost impossible to tell for sure.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Are they from the factory (the cars), or are they connected to a passenger train? Almost looks like personal vehicles being transported while their owners are in the carriages up ahead. Seems like a low volume way to transport cars, two to a flatcar. We usually see them in box cars or on multi-level transports nowadays...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] They're shiny, unregistered and all the same. I'd say they're new.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
The signal indicates "Stop" so the train is awaiting the right to proceed on to a single track section. The train is what was known as a "mixed freight" where a number of different loads were configured together to comprise one train. There appear to be 7 vans of dried goods, a single covered wagon and then the car carriers which are carrying new "ex factory" vehicles which are on delivery to dealers which is why they have no registrations (they hadn't been registered yet). There are no passenger carriages in this type of train. 

Given the wagons on the freight bay on the other platform it could be that vans were being added or disconnected at this point which would explain the chap on the line who would be physically manipulating the couplings for shunting. He would not be aimlessly wandering there and would be part of the train or station crew

Given the poor state of Irish roads, the Irish railway network built up a substantial parcels network which gave fast service for shipping goods all over the country. On the vacant platform a number of items are seen awaiting loading on the next train. What appears to be abandoned luggage was positioned appropriate to where a specific parcels van or guards van would stop. Trains stop at pre-planned points so the station parcels staff would know precisely where a particular vehicle would stop.
